It's difficult to say whether Frank Lloyd's controversial portrayals were intentional or accidental since we don't have access to his personal thoughts and motivations. However, it's worth noting that Lloyd was a director who was known for his attention to detail and meticulous planning, so it's unlikely that he would have included controversial elements in his films without some degree of thought and intention.

That being said, it's also possible that Lloyd's approach to portraying social issues was shaped by the cultural and historical context of his time. Many of Lloyd's films were made during a period of intense social and political upheaval, when issues related to race, class, and nationalism were at the forefront of public discourse. It's possible that Lloyd was simply working within the constraints of his era and trying to navigate the challenges of creating art that was both socially conscious and commercially successful.

Ultimately, it's difficult to know for sure whether Lloyd's controversial portrayals were intentional or accidental, but it's clear that they were an important aspect of his filmmaking style, and they helped to spark important conversations and debates among audiences and critics alike.
